studies.title: Maternal lipid mobilization is essential for embryonic development in a key malaria vector
studies.description: Lipid metabolism is an essential component in reproductive physiology. While lipid mobilization has been implicated in the growth of Plasmodium falciparum malaria parasites in their Anopheles vectors, the role of this process in the reproductive biology of these mosquitoes remains elusive. Here, we show that impairing lipolysis in Anopheles gambiae, the major malaria vectors, leads to embryonic lethality. Embryos derived from females in which we silenced the triglyceride lipase AgTL2 or the lipid storage droplet AgLSD1 develop normally during early embryogenesis but fail to hatch. These embryos show severely impaired metabolism and appear to have compromised neuronal functions. Embryonic lethality is efficiently recapitulated by exposing adult females to broad-spectrum lipase inhibitors prior to blood feeding, unveiling lipolysis as a novel target for inducing mosquito sterility. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the importance of maternal lipid mobilization in embryonic health that could potentially inform studies on human reproduction.

publications.title: Maternal lipid mobilization is essential for embryonic development in a key malaria vector
publications.authorList: Maurice A. Itoe, William Robert Shaw, Iryna Stryapunina, Charles Vidoudez, Duo Peng, Esrah W. Du, Tasneem A. Rinvee, Naresh Singh, Yan Yan, Oleksandr Hulai, Kate E. Thornburg, Flaminia Catteruccia

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description: Briefly, 200 embryos from control (GFP) and TL2 knockdown blood fed Anopheles gambiae females in 3 biological replicates were collected at 4-6 h, 22-24 h and 36-38 h after laying with 1 mL of methanol into a vial containing 5x 2 mm beads.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Embryos were homogenized in a bead-beating homogenizer (Mini-Beadbeater 96, Biospec products) for 5 min at 2400 rpm in a cold block and transferred to 8 mL glass vials (Duran Wheaton Kimble (DWK) Life Sciences, Cat 224744). After rinsing the bead-beater tubes with an additional 1 mL of methanol, 4 mL of cold chloroform was added to each glass vial and vortexed for 1 min. Next 2 mL of ultrapure water was added to each vial and vortexed for another 1 min. Glass vials were centrifuged at 3000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C. In total 3 mL of the upper aqueous phase and 3 mL of the lower chloroform phase were transferred into separate glass vials for metabolomic and lipidomic analyses, respectively. Three extraction blanks were also processed (same extraction but without biomass).


For metabolomics:

Samples were dried under nitrogen flow and resuspended in 50 µL of acetonitrile 25% in water. A pool was created by combining 10 µL of each sample (except blanks).


For lipidomics:

Samples were dried under nitrogen flow and resuspended in 60 µL of chloroform. Each sample was split into two equal aliquots, one for each polarity analysis.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
For metabolomics:

A Vanquish chromatographic system (Thermo Electron North America, Madison, WI, USA) was used. Separation was performed on a ZIC-pHILIC peek-coated column (150 mm x 2.1 mm, 5 µm particles, maintained at 40 °C, Sigma-Aldrich). The flow rate was 0.15 mL/min, expect for the first 30 s where it was ramped from 0.05 to 0.15 mL/min. Mobile phase were 20 mM ammonium carbonate in water with 0.1% ammonium hydroxide for A and acetonitrile 97% in water for B. The consisted of isocratic step of 0.5 min at 93% B, then to 40% B in 18.5 min, then to 0% B in 9 min, followed by an isocratic step at 0% B for 5 min and back to 93% B in 3 min. the column was re-equilibrated at 93% B for 9 min.


For lipidomics:

An Ultimate 3000 chromatographic system (Thermo Electron North America, Madison, WI, USA) was used. Separation was performed on a Biobond C4 column (4.6 x 50 mm, 5 μm, Dikma Technologies). Flow rate was set to 100 µL/min for 5 min with 0% mobile phase B (MB), then switched to 400 µL/min for 50 min, with a linear gradient of MB from 20% to 100%. The column was then washed at 500 µL/min for 8 min at 100% MB before being re-equilibrated for 7 min at 0% MB and 500 µL/min. For the Positive ionization method, mobile phase A (MA) consisted of 5 mM ammonium formate, 0.1 % formic acid and 5% methanol in water, and MB consisted of 5 mM ammonium formate, 0.1% formic acid, 5% water, 35% methanol in isopropanol. For the Negative ionization method, mobile phase A (MA) consisted of 0.03% ammonium hydroxide and 5% methanol in water, and MB consisted of 0.03% ammonium hydroxide, 5% water, 35% methanol in isopropanol.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description:
Metabolomics:

The liquid chromatographic system was coupled to a ID-X tribrid Mass spectrometer (Thermo Electron North America, Madison, WI, USA) fitted with an electrospray source (ESI). Experimental samples were analyzed in MS1 only. The Pool sample was analyzed in MS2/3 in positive and negative mode separately, using the AquireX deepscan mode. For MS1 only data acquisition, data was acquired in switching polarity mode, with a mass resolution of120,000. The mass accuracy was within a 3 ppm range. The RF lens was set at 30% and data was acquired in the range 65-1000 m/z. Internal calibration was used.  For MS2/3 data acquisition in positive mode, data was acquired in data depend mode in positive mode only. The MS1 scan used the same settings as the MS1 only acquisition.


First a solvent blank and an injection of the pool were run, acquiring only MS1 data. All peaks found in the blank were added to an exclusion list. All peak found in the Pool sample were added to an inclusion list. The pool sample was then reinjected and analyzed in MS2/3 mode, using the inclusion and exclusion lists to select the ions to fragment. Data dependent MS2 was acquired with a 1.5 m/z isolation window, HCD assisted collision (selecting the best energy from 15, 25, 45, 65) and analyzing the resulting fragments in the orbitrap with a 30,000 resolution. Data dependent MS3 was acquired on the top 3 fragments using a 40% CID fragmentation and analyzing the fragment in the orbitrap at 15,000 resolution. All peaks that were fragmented in the run were then added to the exclusion list and removed from the inclusion list. The sample was reinjected a total 5 times to achieve as much MS2/3 coverage as possible. For MS2/3 data acquisition in negative mode: Data was acquired the same way as MS2/3 positive mode, but in negative mode.


Lipidomics:

The liquid chromatographic system was coupled to a Q-Exactive plus Mass spectrometer (Thermo Electron North America, Madison, WI, USA) fitted with an electrospray source (ESI). For positive mode, data was acquired in positive mode only. MS1 data was acquired at 70,000 resolution. the mass accuracy was within a 5 ppm range. the RF lens was set at 50% and data was acquired in the range 150-2000 m/z. MS2 data was acquired on the top 5 ions, using an apex trigger (5-35 ms) and 30 s dynamic exclusion. Ions were isolated with a 1 m/z isolation window and fragmented by HCD with stepped NCE 20 and 30. The fragments were analyzed at 35,000 resolution. For negative mode, data was acquired the same way as the positive mode, but in negative mode.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
For all files, msConvert (ProteoWizard) was used to generate the mzML files, with peak picking selected to centroid the data.


For metabolomics:

Data was analyzed in compound discoverer 3.3 SP2 (Thermofisher Scientific). For each sample, peaks were detected, de-adducted and polarity were combined. MS2/3 data from the pool samples were associated with the corresponding peaks. If a compound in samples was always less than 5 fold the average intensity in the blanks, it was removed from the results. Data was gap filled by reintegrating peaks or local noise for samples where a peak was not original detected. Intensities were median centered by sample.


For lipidomics:

Data was analyzed in Lipidsearch 4.2.27 (Mitsui Knowledge Industry, University of Tokyo). For each sample, peaks were detected and de-adducted. Data was manually curated and if necessary re-integrated. The data was then exported to excel. Positive and negative mode data was combined in one table. The blank average was calculated for each compound, multiplied by 5 and subtracted from the intensity in each sample (and set to 0 if the resulting intensity was negative).

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
Metabolomics

Compounds were identified in Compound Discoverer (see data transformation). All identification were manually inspected. Basic stereochemistry was removed from most identification from the databases results. Level 1: Identification was based first on an internal mzVault library with matching retention time created using authentic standards.

Level 2: Identification was based secondly on matches (based on MS trees) with the online mzCloud database. Level 3: No good identification was obtained by library match, however some information was obtained from the MS2, or there was a retention time match with a standard without MS2 match. The name contains the description. Level 4: For the other compounds, compound discoverer calculated the formulae based on the observed m/z within 3 ppm. Formulae were ranked based on ppm, distribution of the natural isotopes and fragments if available. The top formula was assigned then automatically based on a combined score. Level 5: This was assigned to compounds where no formula could be calculated.


Lipidomics

Compounds were identified in LipidSearch (see data transformation). All identification were manually inspected. When multiple identification were possible for one peak, the identification with the best score in the most sample was selected. All identification are based on MS2 fragmentation, using known fragmentation rules. Compounds without any hit for lipids are not reported.
